title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Postal Fund

description.narrative: Zimbabwe rhino management policy includes marking or tagging individual rhinos to facilitate regular, frequent individual monitoring for security purposes, and dehorning (removing rhino horns) in regions of perceived threat to reduce the incentive and rewards for poachers. Funding will support the costs necessary to hire experienced veterinarians and pilots to locate and immobilize at least twenty rhinos for ear-notching and dehorning.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: Zimbabwe rhino management policy includes marking or tagging individual rhinos to facilitate regular, frequent individual monitoring for security purposes, and dehorning (removing rhino horns) in regions of perceived threat to reduce the incentive and rewards for poachers. Funding will support the costs necessary to hire experienced veterinarians and pilots to locate and immobilize rhinos in Matopos National Park for ear-notching and dehorning.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This grant will support veterinary inverventions for black and white rhinos in the South East lowveld of Zimbabwe for emergency health care and essential management operations in order to improve rhino security, monitoring of individuals and metapopulation management. The recipient will work with an experienced team to locate and immobilize rhinos when necessary in order to treat the animals for a) emergency veterinary treatment of snare injuries and other injuries, b) ear-notching and fitting horn implant transmitters to aid rhino monitoring, c) translocating rhinos in vulnerable areas to places of greater safety, d) dehorning to reduce poaching risk.

title.narrative: Increased security along the Zimbabwean-Mozambique border in Gonarezhou National Park, Zimbabwe

description.narrative: The project supports park protection activities in Gonarezhou Naitonal Park in Zimbabwe, which houses one of Zimbabwe's largest remaining elephant populations. Specific activities include the refurbishment of a ranger training center inside the park, basic and specialized training courses for rangers, establishment of a scene-of-the-crime unit to investigate poaching incidents, and operational support for aerial surveillance.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Increased security along the Zimbabwean-Mozambique border in Gonarezhou National Park, Zimbabwe

description.narrative: This project supports park protection activities in Gonarezhou National Park in Zimbabwe, which houses one of Zimbabwes largest remaining elephant populations. Specific activities include the refurbishment of a ranger training center inside the park, basic and specialized training courses for rangers, establishment of a scene-of-the-crime unit to investigate poaching incidents, and operational support for aerial surveillance.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Supporting the management of the Elephant Trade Information System (ETIS): Analyzing illegal trade in ivory for CITES

description.narrative: This grant will support the collection of data necessary to monitor and analyze trends in illegal trade in ivory in elephant range states and illegal consumer markets. The ETIS database holds data on 21,000 seizures of ivory. Funds will support analysis of trends since 2012 (when data were compiled for the 16th Conference of the Parties to the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species) through 2013.

title.narrative: Matobo National Park: Annual darting and immobilisation of black and white rhino for routine dehorning and ear-notching to aid monitoring and protection strategies

description.narrative: The government of Zimbabwe has decided to dehorn black and white rhinos in Matobo National Park routinely to minimize the risk of poaching and to notch the rhinos ears to facilitate individual monitoring for security and management. This grant will support a partner organization to conduct the veterinary operations to immobilize rhinos for dehorning and notching in 2016.

description.narrative: This grant supports veterinary interventions for black and white rhinos in the southeast lowveld of Zimbabwe for emergency health care and essential management operations in order to improve rhino security, monitoring of individuals and metapopulation management. The recipient will work with an experienced team to locate and immobilize rhinos when necessary in order to treat the animals for a) emergency veterinary treatment of snare injuries and other injuries, b) ear-notching and installing non-invasive devices to aid rhino monitoring, c) translocating rhinos in vulnerable areas to places of greater safety, d) dehorning to reduce poaching risk.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino monitoring and security vehicles-Zimbabwe, 2016

description.narrative: The Lowveld RhinoTrust is responsible for the monitoring and management of the black and white rhino populations in southeastern Zimbabwe. In face of increasing incursions by poachers, dedicated vehicles are needed in order to provide reliable transportation for rhino monitoring and security. Funds will be used to purchase and operate two vehicles for the rhino teams working at Bubye and Save Valley conservancies.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Ensuring the long term security of the elephant population of Gonarezhou National Park, Zimbabwe

description.narrative: Funds will support expanded security measures and community engagement in and around Gonarezhou National Park. Activities will include foot, mobile, and canine patrols in poaching hotspots and in vulnerable areas such as the Mozambique border, river floodplains, and pans in central Gonarezhou. Other activities include education and awareness raising efforts to bring attention to the damage being done by poisoning and raising the profile of the Parks elephants through the iconic elephant project.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

description.narrative: This grant supports veterinary interventions for black and white rhinos in the southeast lowveld of Zimbabwe for emergency health care and essential management operations in order to improve rhino security, monitoring of individuals and metapopulation management. The recipient will work with an experienced team to locate and immobilize rhinos when necessary in order to treat the animals for a) emergency veterinary treatment of snare injuries, bullet wounds, and other injuries, b) ear-notching and installing non-invasive devices to aid rhino monitoring, c) translocating rhinos in vulnerable areas to places of greater safety, d) dehorning to reduce poaching risk.

title.narrative: Matobo National Park: annual darting and immobilisation of black and white rhino for routine dehorning and ear-notching to aid monitoring and protection strategies

description.narrative: This project funds essential annual operations in Matobo National Park, the most viable remaining population of rhinos on public land in Zimbabwe. The government of Zimbabwe has decided to dehorn black and white rhinos in Matobo National Park routinely to minimize the risk of poaching and to notch the rhinos ears to facilitate individual monitoring for security and management. This grant will support a partner organization to hire a qualified, experienced veterinarian and capture team to conduct the veterinary operations necessary to immobilize rhinos for dehorning and notching in 2018 and operating expenses to conduct monitoring of all individual rhinos throughout the year.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Developing a new, cost-effective rhino tracking system in Zimbabwe

description.narrative: Because of their horns and neck shape, it is challenging to fit tracking devices on rhinos. Two rhino conservation organizations have joined forces with a technology company that specializes in the production of miniaturized, robust transmitters to produce a new smaller tracking device specifically for rhinos. Funds will be used to produce the first 100 transmitters and to pilot test them in conservancies in Zimbabwe. The anticipated outcome of this project is the development of a fully functional rhino tracking system that is more efficient and cost-effective than any other systems currently in use. If successful, this will allow more detailed locational monitoring of rhinos and better targeted protection.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Raising community awareness of rhino conservation in rural Zimbabwe

description.narrative: The Bubye Valley Conservancy and the Save Valley Conservancy in the southeast lowveld of Zimbabwe contain Zimbabwes largest black rhino populations and significant numbers of white rhinos. However, the rhinos are under threat from targeted poaching, and suffer injuries and death from snares set to kill smaller wild animals for bushmeat. This project aims to raise awareness about rhinos and other wildlife and promote tolerance and appreciation of wildlife through an education program that will reach 145 primary schools in or near rhino range.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: REINTRODUCTION OF BLACK RHINO INTO GONAREZHOU NATIONAL PARK, ZIMBABWE #2: LONG-TERM SECURITY THROUGH TARGETED TECHNOLOGY, PROTECTION AND MONITORING

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A CONSERVATION EFFORT IN GONAREZHOU NATIONAL PARK, ZIMBABWE BY ENSURING THE SECURITY OF THE REINTRODUCED BLACK RHINOCEROS POPULATION AND MAINTAINING RHINOCEROS HEALTH, BREEDING POTENTIAL, AND DISPERSAL AND SETTLEMENT PATTERNS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE THE SOUTHERN CENTRAL BLACK RHINOCEROS SUBSPECIES BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF THE ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRADE. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) SUPPORTING RHINOCEROS SECURITY (2) CONDUCTING MONITORING OF THE POPULATION AND (3) CARRYING OUT AN ANNUAL RHINOCEROS AUDIT FOR THE REESTABLISHMENT OF A VIABLE BLACK RHINOCEROS POPULATION.

title.narrative: REINTRODUCTION OF BLACK RHINO INTO GONAREZHOU NATIONAL PARK, ZIMBABWE #2: LONG-TERM SECURITY THROUGH TARGETED TECHNOLOGY, PROTECTION AND MONITORING

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in Gonarezhou National Park, Zimbabwe by ensuring the security of the reintroduced black rhinoceros population and maintaining rhinoceros health, breeding potential, and dispersal and settlement patterns. This project is intended to conserve the Southern Central black rhinoceros subspecies by addressing the impacts of the illegal wildlife trade. Specific activities include: (1) supporting rhinoceros security; (2) conducting monitoring of the population; and (3) carrying out an annual rhinoceros audit for the reestablishment of a viable black rhinoceros population.

title.narrative: CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR RHINOCEROS MANAGEMENT OPERATIONS IN ZIMBABWE'S LOWVELD

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in the Lowveld region of Zimbabwe by supporting management operations to extend and secure the rhinoceros range. This project is intended to conserve black rhinoceros and their habitat by addressing rhinoceros health and monitoring. Specific activities include: (1) providing veterinary interventions for rhinoceros; and (2) purchasing vehicle and supplies for long- term population monitoring

THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE RHINOCEROS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF TARGETED POACHING. description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A CONSERVATION EFFORT IN MATOPOS NATIONAL PARK, ZIMBABWE BY AIDING POPULATION MONITORING AND PROTECTION STRATEGIES. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE RHINOCEROS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF TARGETED POACHING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) ORGANIZING RHINOCEROS MANAGEMENT OPERATIONS WITH GOVERNMENT PARTNERS (2) SUPPORTING TECHNICAL PERSONNEL (3) IMMOBILIZING RHINOCEROS FOR DEHORNING AND EAR-NOTCHING AND (4) COLLECTING BIOMETRIC DATA TO INFORM POPULATION MANAGEMENT.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: MATOPOS NATIONAL PARK: ANNUAL DARTING AND IMMOBILISATION OF BLACK AND WHITE RHINO FOR ROUTINE DEHORNING AND EAR-NOTCHING TO AID MONITORING AND PROTECTION STRATEGIES.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in Matopos National Park, Zimbabwe by aiding population monitoring and protection strategies. This project is intended to conserve rhinoceros and their habitat by addressing the impacts of targeted poaching. Specific activities include: (1) organizing rhinoceros management operations with government partners; (2) supporting technical personnel; (3) immobilizing rhinoceros for dehorning and ear-notching; and (4) collecting biometric data to inform population management.

title.narrative: ENSURING THE LONG-TERM SECURITY OF THE ELEPHANT POPULATION OF GONAREZHOU NATIONAL PARK, ZIMBABWE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to promote the long-term recovery of an important elephant population in Zimbabwe, including expansion into adjacent safari hunting areas and cross-border corridors. The elephants of Gonarezhou National Park, most recently estimated at more than 10,000 individuals, are part of the Greater Limpopo transfrontier population that extends into Mozambique and South Africa. In contrast to other neighboring sites, the documented number of poached elephants has been declining in Gonarezhou as anti-poaching effort has increased. Aerial survey and elephant collaring data indicate, however, that elephants are remaining within the safety of park boundaries and are not expanding into adjacent areas of available habitat. This project attempts to change that dynamic by maintaining anti-poaching pressure where park management has been successful and working towards greater security in adjoining wildlife areas in Zimbabwe and neighboring Mozambique. Specific activities include: (1) operational support for park rangers, including foot and vehicle patrols, basic equipment, improvements to the radio network, vehicle support, and anti-poaching infrastructure development along the Zimbabwe-Mozambique border
